an3.109:4.1: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha,
an3.109:4.2: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an3.109:4.4: “Householder, when the mind is unprotected, deeds of body, speech, and mind are unprotected.
an3.109:4.5: When deeds are unprotected, they become corrupted.
an3.109:4.6: When deeds are corrupted, they become rotten.
an3.109:4.7: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are rotten will not have a good death.
an3.109:5.1: It’s like a bungalow with a bad roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls are unprotected.
an3.109:6.1: In the same way, when the mind is unprotected, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are unprotected. …
an3.109:6.4: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are rotten will not have a good death.
an3.109:7.1: When the mind is protected, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are protected.
an3.109:7.2: When deeds are protected, they don’t become corrupted.
an3.109:7.3: When deeds aren’t corrupted, they don’t become rotten.
an3.109:7.4: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind aren’t rotten will have a good death.
an3.109:8.1: It’s like a bungalow with a good roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls are protected.
an3.109:9.1: In the same way, when the mind is protected, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are protected. …
an3.109:9.4: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind aren’t rotten will have a good death.”
